docs.snippet: Rising resentment against elite technology firms manifests itself in demonstrations at public bus stops in San Francisco, where private shuttle buses ferry engineers to work....
docs.lead_paragraph: Rising resentment against elite technology firms manifests itself in demonstrations at public bus stops in San Francisco, where private shuttle buses ferry engineers to work.

headline.main: Tech Rides Are Focus of Hostility in Bay Area
headline.print_headline: Tech Rides Are Focus of Hostility in Bay Area

docs.abstract: Rising resentment against elite technology firms is manifesting itself in demonstrations at public bus stops in San Francisco, where private shuttle buses ferry engineers to work at campuses of Silicon Valley giants like Google, Apple, Facebook, Yahoo and eBay; buses, which illegally use city stops, have become focus of hostility among residents and an unlikely rallying point for activists.

headline.print_headline: Taking Aim at Android, After a Jilting at Nokia

docs.abstract: Former Nokia executives aim to compete with Google's dominant Android mobile operating system with new smartphone built using open-source software; Jolla was formed to develop operating system that Nokia discarded when it ended plans for its own software and teamed with Microsoft to focus on Windows-based phones.

headline.main: The Plus in Google Plus? It’s Mostly for Google
headline.print_headline: The Plus in Google Plus? It’s Mostly for Google

docs.abstract: Google Plus, social network that receives only moderate traffic, is extremely valuable to company by allowing it to gather an ever-richer trove of the personal information that advertisers covet; signing up for Plus allows Google access to a user's behavior across all of its services, even if the social network itself is never used.

headline.main: Will the Net Stay Neutral?

docs.abstract: Joe Nocera Op-Ed column holds the Comcast-Time Warner Cable merger presents only the latest threat to net neutrality; expresses doubt that the Federal Communications Commission will be able or willing to sufficiently regulate the broadband industry; says Google's ambitious ISP project, Google Fiber, may be able to achieve net neutrality through competition, even if regulation fails.
